metadata./Title: Syringocystadenocarcinoma of the perianal region: a case report

sections.Introduction:
Introduction Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum is an extremely rare malignant adnexal tumor that typically 
arises from a papilliferous syringocystadenoma (World Health Organization classification of skin tumors, 2018.). This 
tumor predominantly occurs in the cephalic region.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We present the case of a 68-year-old Moroccan male with no significant medical history who 
presented with a slowly progressing skin mass in the perianal region. Despite the chronic nature of the swelling, 
the patient remained in overall good health. Physical examination revealed a firm 2.3-cm mass in the perianal area, 
with no other remarkable findings. The patient underwent surgical excision of the mass. Macroscopic examination 
showed a solid-cystic, rounded mass. Microscopic examination revealed a malignant adnexal tumor with apocrine differentiation and papillary architecture. Immunohistochemistry was positive for p63, cytokeratin 7 (CK7), and smooth 
muscle actin, with a Ki67 labeling index in 60% of tumor cells, and negative for p16. The diagnosis of syringocystade nocarcinoma papilliferum was confirmed. A further surgical resection was performed, and the patient’s postoperative 
course was unremarkable.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum is an extremely rare tumor, with its occurrence in the perianal 
region being particularly uncommon. This case contributes to the limited literature on this malignancy, highlighting 
its clinical and pathological features.
Keywords  Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum, Perianal, Pathology, Literature review
Introduction
Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum is an extremely 
rare malignant adnexal tumor that typically arises from 
a papilliferous syringocystadenoma [1]. This tumor pre dominantly occurs in the cephalic region. Given the rar ity of syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum [1, 2], we report a case of this tumor occurring in an unusual 
location, accompanied by a review of all cases reported 
in literature. The objective of this work is to clarify the 
epidemiological and histopathological characteristics of 
this malignancy by reviewing the 46 cases documented to 
date.
Case presentation
Patient information
We report the case of a 68-year-old Moroccan male with 
no significant medical history who presented with a peri anal mass that had been gradually enlarging over a period 
of 6 months. Despite the chronic nature of the condition, 
the patient remained in good general health, although the 
mass caused discomfort during defecation and sitting.

Diagnostic assessment
Macroscopic examination revealed a solid-cystic mass. 
Microscopic examination showed infiltrative malignant 
adnexal tumor proliferation with apocrine differentia tion, arranged in clusters of varying sizes, some with cri briform and papillary structures, occasionally centered 
by necrotic areas of neoplastic cells exhibiting cytonu clear atypia and abnormal mitoses. There were also areas 
of squamous differentiation. No in situ carcinoma or vas cular invasion was identified (Figs.  1, 2). Immunohisto chemical analysis demonstrated positivity for p63 (Fig.  3), 
CK7 (Fig.  4), and smooth muscle actin (Fig.  5), while p16 
was negative (Fig.  6). The Ki67 proliferation index was 
60% (Fig.  7). The final diagnosis was syringocystadeno carcinoma papilliferum.
Therapeutic intervention
The patient underwent additional surgical resection, 
and subsequent microscopic examination confirmed 
the absence of residual tumor. Radiological evaluation 
revealed no further abnormalities.
Followup and outcomes
The patient’s postoperative course was uneventful, with 
no signs of recurrence.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusion
Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum is a malignant 
adnexal tumor with apocrine differentiation, primar ily occurring in the cephalic region. This malignancy is 
extremely rare [2, 3], with only 46 cases reported to date; 
our case represents the 47th. Clinically, the tumor may 
present as a solid, solid-cystic, ulcerated, or inflamma tory nodule, often covered with crusts due to apocrine 
secretion [10, 11]. Owing to the rarity of reported cases, 
the clinical characteristics are not well understood. In 
Table  1, we summarize all cases reported in literature up 
to January 2024. The mean age of onset is 66.24  years, 
with 41% of patients being female. Perianal involve ment accounts for 8.6% of cases. The average tumor size 
is approximately 3  cm (Table  1). Histologically, these 
tumors exhibit a papillary architecture with cribriform 
and solid masses. The neoplastic cells display cytonuclear 
atypia and abnormal mitoses. Squamous differentiation 
is common, while vascular invasion is rare, consistent 
with the histological findings in our case. The presence of in  situ carcinoma, characterized by similar microscopic 
features but confined by a basement membrane, is noted 
in 39% of cases in literature (Table  1). These tumors 
typically stain positive for CK7 and CAM5.2 [1, 4, 5, 8, 
9]. The primary differential diagnosis is with syringoad enoma papilliferum, which lacks significant atypia, inva sion, and asymmetry [1, 6]. Treatment involves complete 
surgical excision [7]. The prognosis of syringocystadeno carcinoma papilliferum is marked by the risk of recur rence and metastasis in cases of incomplete resection; 
otherwise, the prognosis is generally favorable [12–14].
Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum is an excep tionally rare tumor, and its occurrence in the perianal 
region is indeed an unusual finding. By meticulously 
reviewing the existing literature, we aim to elucidate the 
key characteristics of this malignancy.
